Behaviours
When a group of pills exceeds viewport width or the maximum visible pill count, there
are two options on how containers can present the overflow:
Fluid width container
First option is to present the pills on fluid width containers which grow horizontally on a
single row. They can be horizontally scrollable, and the container width is determined
by the length of its contents.
In this variant, all pills are laid out horizontally, and users can simply scroll through the contents.
Scrolling
We use the carousel when pills will align with the edge of the screen, preventing the
next pill from being displayed. This helps a user know that the overflow can be scrolled.
Overflow button
Pill Label Pill Label Pill Label > Pill Label Pill Label Pill Label
Overflow controls indicates there are other pills to be scrolled when the next pill is not present on the screen.
Fixed-width container
Second option is to present the pills on fixed-width containers which wrap pills onto
new rows. The container height can be controlled by determining a maximum number
of visible pills.
When the number of maximum visible pills is set, an overflow button allows users to
reveal the remaining content. Actions bound to the overflow button can vary.

Pills vs. Buttons
Visually, pills and buttons are strikingly similar—but their usage differs, as do what they
represent.
Pills reflect a piece of data that can be applied, selected, submitted or modified.
They're typically labelled with an adjective (e.g. Soft, Firm) or a noun (e.g. Kitchen,
Bathroom).
Buttons reflect an action labelled with a verb (eg. shop, apply, continue) and once
pressed, they perform the action.
Home furnishing categories used as pills to filter an image feed. Button actions used to submit colour preferences.
Pills as selection
This pattern uses pills as an alternative to checkboxes, capturing a user's selections,
after which those selections are either saved or submitted using a button. In some
instances adding an affordance as a leading or trailing icon can help the user identify
that the group is capturing a selection instead of submitting actions.

Pills as input
This pattern is most similar to a group of buttons. The group typically does not have
selections or activations, but instead, the data is representative of an input (e.g. a
chatbot suggestion) or a link to an application page displaying that data.
& Support Bot
When selected, the pill inputs the data it represents to initiate some sort of change, such as a conversation with a chatbot.
Dismissible Pills
Dismissible Pills with trailing close icons, indicating that pressing them will remove
them from the group, are used to filter products or topics.
